div.p: 1. Took the boat of 9 o’clock from Leyden to Haerlem—arrived there at 1. Dined at the White Fleece. Very Sociable company in the boat. Two or three Frieslanders. A Jew and his Daughter, who told us she was going to be married, and had never seen her Lover but twice. Said she did not like it, but was obliged to submit.— Boat from Haerlem at 4. we were alone in the Roof. Arrived at the Arms of Amsterdam at about 7. Mr: Bourne called on us soon afterwards and pass’d an hour.— Reading by way of amusement on my tour Terence’s Comedies.

2. Called this morning on Mr: Bourne. Then at Mr: Hubbard’s and Mr: W. Willink’s, neither of whom were at home. Evening with Mr: Bourne at the french Comedy.— Company of Dubus, and not very good. Charles &Caroline, a Drame moral. Revolutionary and dull. Le Petit Matelot. Music tolerable.— Wrote in the forenoon.

3. Writing all the forenoon. With Mr: Bourne at the German Play. Performance by Jews, and singing tolerable. Remainder of the Evening with Mr: Bourne.— Captain Mackay. Mr: Rutgers and Mr: Tucker— Weather very cold.

4. Writing again all the morning. Dined at Table d’Hôte. Only one Gentleman of the company besides ourselves. Evening at a Concert at the German Play-house. Performers between 60 and 70.— A very excellent violin— Met Mr: G. Apthorp there.

5. Mr Apthorp and Captain Mackay called on me this morning. Mr: W. Willink and Mr: Hubbard in the afternoon. Letters from America and from London. One from the President of the United States. Evening and Supper with Captain Mackay. Large Company and a very sumptuous entertainment: late home.

6. Returned to the Hague in the Stage Waggon. Left Amsterdam at 9 in the morning. Two Dutchmen in the carriage with us. Not much conversation, but abundance of smoaking. Weather very cold, and changeable. Alternate storms of snow and sunshine. The canals not yet closed, but freezing over and full of snow. Met several of the Ice Schuyts.— We came through Leyden an usual road for the Stage, and reached home at about 6 in the Evening. My brother went to the ball.— Evening at home.

7. Clear cold day. Some writing. Walk in the wood and met Bielfeld. Had called at his lodgings without finding him.— Execution of a french soldier for striking his officer, upon guard, which we heard, but did not see. Called in the afternoon at Mr: Veerman’s but they were not at home. At Madam Dumas’s. Evening chiefly at home. Finished reading the 13th: book of Cicero’s familiar Epistles. It consists almost entirely of Letters of Recommendation.

8. Renewed my morning translation from Tacitus. Wrote a Note to the Committee of external Relations conformably to the Letter received at Amsterdam from the Secretary of State. Carried it to Mr: Van Leyden’s. He was not at home. Left it therefore with his Servant. Writing.— Evening at Mr: Noël’s.— Cards. Whist, with General Rewbell: Mr: Gevers, and Mr: —— 14th: book of the Epistles. To his wife.

9. Called again at Mr: Van Leyden’s, and again he was not at home.— Returned a Visit to Mr: Van der Goes. Did not find him. Visit to Mr: d’Anduaga the Spanish Minister. Had considerable conversation with him. He says that Spain will not cede Louisiana to the french. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. conversation with Madam.— 15th: Book of Cicero’s Epistles.— Public dispatches during his proconsulate in Cilicia. Letters to Cato, the Marcelli, Cassius Trebonius &c.

10. In consequence of Letters from Mr: Bourne received this morning and this afternoon, determined to go again to Amsterdam to-morrow. Could not engage a place in the Stage, as they were all taken. Sent for a Chaise.— Writing Letters.— Began the 16th: book of the Epistles.— To Tiro.

11. Set out for Amsterdam in a Chaise, with Whitcomb, at 9 this morning. Arrived a little after three. Mr: Bourne called on me at about 5. Arranged with him the mode of drawing upon the Treasury for 20,000 Dollars, and remitting to Mr: De Wolf at Antwerp 49700 florins. This transaction appears in my Letter book.— Remainder of the Evening, writing the Letters.

12. Early in the morning, drew a couple of bills of Exchange upon the Treasury and finished the papers proper for the transaction. Went with them to Mr: Bourne’s and after several little delays such as always occur in going through any business finally made all the arrangements so as to get into my Chaise on my return to the Hague, at about half past one. Called at Mr: Bourne’s, and at the Post-Office to leave a letter for Mr: De Wolf. Reached home a little after eight in the Evening.— Weather has much moderated. But the canals are all frozen over.— Roads not very good owing to the thaw.

13. Writing all the morning. Dined by invitation at the Patriotic Society, in the house which was formerly the Prince’s Cabinet and Library. There were about an hundred persons at table, generally members of the Assembly; the Corps Diplomatique, and Officers of the Armies; french and Batavian. The Dinner was given on occasion of the Decree of Unity and Indivisibility by the National Assembly. The Citizen Buys after dinner read a speech, which appeared to be of Noël’s composition. It was an address to the Batavian Citizens present congratulating them upon the decree of Indivisibility. There was among other things introduced a compliment to the foreign Ministers present, decent enough. About half a dozen toasts were drank. The Batavian & French Republics. The powers in friendship with them &c.— Before dinner the President of the National Assembly and Mr: Van Leyden informed me that my Note lately presented, had been read at a meeting of the Committee of foreign affairs. That at the next general meeting they would probably resolve to propose to the Assembly the appointment of persons to confer with me upon the subject of its contents.— The President’s name is Van Lennep.— Came home at about 9.

14. Short walk with Bielfeld in the forenoon. Weather very bad. Dined at M. de Schubart’s. Large Company. Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Cards. Quadrill. Company chiefly the same as at dinner. Very busy, writing.

15. Wrote to the Secretary of State and to Mr: Bourne. Visit in the forenoon from the General Degent, with his aid-de-camp, and General Rewbell. General Degent is now, commander in chief of the Army of the North. He returns to-morrow to Utrecht, where his head Quarters are.— He expressed a strong desire for Peace, and said there was scarce a family in France some member of which had not emigrated.— Evening at home. Called at Mr: Veerman’s, but Madam was not at home. At Madam Dumas’s, who had company. Continued the last book of Cicero’s familiar Epistles to Tiro, but could not finish it. My brother dined at Mr: Van Leyden’s.
16. Visit this forenoon from General Van Meyeren. Something of a coxcomb.— Wrote my father. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s— Music.— Finished the 16th. and last book of Cicero’s familiar Epistles.

17. Very cold day. Visit from Mr. Tucker on his way from Rotterdam to Amsterdam. from Bielfeld. Dined alone. Evening and Supper at Mr: Scholten’s.— Cards. Reverse with Madam de Schubart General Rewbell and Mr: Cneiff.— Home very late.

18. The weather has moderated, and a little rain has made the streets excessively slippery. Visit to Genl. Rewbell. He is a brother of Rewbell the member of the french Directory.— Remainder of the day at home. Finished reading the Hecyra of Terence, the last of his Comedies. I recognize the beautiful simplicity of his language, and the want of the vis comica according to the character given him by Caesar. The great similarity of the plots to one another is also an objection. The discrimination of characters in general is feeble, and the moral seldom complete and accurate. Upon the whole the good modern Comedies appear to me much superior to these.— Began also the Letters of Cicero to Atticus. But by way of preface read first the life of Atticus by Cornelius Nepos. Consulted the Abbé de St: Réal’s translation and Notes so that I could only begin upon the Letters themselves and read two of them.

19. The rain has taken off the glare from the Streets. Weather dull.— Short walk, and very busy, writing Letters. Read a few more letters to Atticus. Evening and supper at Mr: Bosset’s. Company in general Diplomatic. Cards. Reversi with Madam de Schubart, General Rewbell & Mr: Noël. Madam Scholten conversed with me while at supper concerning Greanleaf. Says he has obtained his divorce in Rhode-Island, and is married to Miss Allen.

20. The suppers and late Evenings make late mornings and I lose my feast upon Tacitus before breakfast. Not up till after 8. Just at daylight however.— Writing day. My brother in the Evening at the Ball. Went with Bielfeld to Reuterswerd’s. Small party. Cards. Quadrill with success.

21. My letter book will best supply the place of a Journal.— Evening with Mr: & Madam Veerman, at the Dutch subscription Comedy. Siegfried van Lindenberg.— I did not well understand it. Het Eyland van Verwarring or the Island of confusion, imitated from Shakespeare’s Comedy of Errors. Performance indifferent. The actors are principally what they call Amateurs or Liefhebbers. Most of them wanted the habit of the stage, or ease of practice, as well as grace & noblesse of air & demeanour.

22. Visit this morning from. Mr: Geervliet an initiate of Mr: Veerman. From Bielfeld. Walk with him in the wood and met Reuterswärd— Very busy writing. Evening at Mr: Noël’s party. Whist with M. D’Anduaga, General Rewbell and Mr: Gevers.

23. Party this Evening at Mr: Dumely’s. Company large. Quadrill with Madlle: Westreen, Bielfeld, and a young man by the name of Perponcher. Every body enquiring what the U. States have done to offend the french Republic.
24. At length have a moment of leisure upon my hands. Opportunity to read a little. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Conversation with Madam. Have been obliged for some time to neglect my Cicero.

25. Bielfeld called on us in the forenoon. Went with him to see the Skaiters. My brother dined at Mr: Macqueen’s. Evening cold. Reading the letters of Cicero to Atticus, with the Abbé de St: Real’s french translation and Notes. Those letters are more difficult than those ad familiares. It is a task almost desperate to read familiarly the Latin language. With all the pains I have taken I fear never to acquire it.

26. An Extremely cold day.— Walk an hour before dinner.— Read a few papers of the Rambler. Evening at home the whole of it reading the sixteenth Letter of the first book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus.— With the french translation and notes I found it however very difficult to understand.

27. Second very cold day. Same walk however as yesterday. Read some more papers in the Rambler. and finished the first book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus. I fear I am taking more than necessary pains for a knowledge of inadequate compensation. The more I advance the more I meet of obstacles to the attainment.

28. Weather has moderated. Rain most of the forenoon, deprived me of a long walk. Took therefore a short one. Reading a new work of Madame de Stael, upon the influence of the Passions on the happiness of individuals and of Nations. Very ingenious.— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.— Stove in my chamber.

29. Moderate weather still. Very busy writing all the forenoon.— Began to read the second Book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus.— Could read only the first letter.— Evening at Mr: Noël’s party. Very much crowded. Home early.
30. After writing industriously in the forenoon, Walk alone in the wood. Walking indifferent. Bielfeld called on me towards Evening. Went together to Mr: Cneiff’s. Cards. Quadrill.

div.p: 31. Letter to my friend in London.— Walk alone before dinner. Weather remarkably mild. Evening at home to close the year with sober meditation— Not perfectly well.

Day. Rise generally at about 7. which at this Season is an hour before day-light. Read and translate a page from Tacitus. Breakfast at 9 1/2. Dress. Attend to writing, or business till 2. Walk. dine 3 1/2. from 5 to 10. reading Cicero, or go into Company. Bed at about 11.

With the commencement of the present year I began the practice of noting monthly the usual distribution of my employments and amusements through the course of the day. A practice which is not without its use for my own retrospection. The five first months of this year, spent in London were a period of leisure accidentally given me, and too much of which I allowed to the indulgence of indolence. The seven last months pass’d at the Hague have on the contrary been a time of as steady and constant application as ever occurred in the course of my life. I have endeavoured to contract the habit of early rising, and although since the commencement of the Winter, the severity and darkness of the Season have produced some relaxation in the execution of my determination, yet I have maintained it upon the whole with less flexibility than I apprehended I should. I have in a great measure repaired to my own satisfaction the loss of my time in the dissipation of London, and have now only to hope for resolution and health to continue the same degree of industry, with some variation in my objects of pursuit.— With my conduct also since my return from England I am more content than I was there, and in the course of seven months I can have nothing essential to regret. I have indeed happily nothing vicious to reproach myself with, during the whole year, though I remember with the regret which I hope will tend to my improvement many errors, and some follies. At least I have not knowingly injured any human being, and I can form no more fervent prayer to Heaven than that at the termination of every succeeding year which may be granted me, and at the end of life my own heart may yield me a testimony as pure and as favourable as it does at this moment.
